mainmatter.p: A discrete vector field (DVF) of degree p on an algebraic cellular complex is given by a collection of pairs of cells ( \sigma , \tau ), where \sigma is a regular face of the degree p cell \tau, standing for a vector pointing from \sigma to \tau, which we will write as \overrightharpoon { \sigma \tau }. We require that every cell appears at most once in these vectors.

A DVF naturally partitions the cells into three kinds: the sources, the targets, and the rest of the cells are called critical cells. This name comes from the analogy to Morse theory. Indeed there is a notion of discrete Morse function.

frontmatter.title: Regular face in an algebraic cellular complex

mainmatter.p: Given an algebraic cellular complex and a cell \sigma, a regular face of \sigma is a cell whose coefficient in d \sigma is \pm 1.

An algebraic cellular complex (or ACC) is a chain complex of free abelian groups. The generators are called cells, and the boundary maps can be expressed using the generators as a basis, yielding the incidence matrices.

More precisely, we may define an ACC as a sequence of sets C_ \bullet, with a sequence of functions d : C_k \to \mathbb {Z}[C_{k-1}], such that d^2 = 0 is satisfied. When a generator has non-zero coefficient in some d \sigma, the generator is called a face of \sigma.
Note that the generators of these chain groups are canonically chosen as part of the data. So a more accurate definition is a chain complex in the Kleisli category of abelian groups.

frontmatter.title: Discrete field lines can branch and merge

mainmatter.p: Although we make an analogy between a discrete vector field and a vector field, the field lines of a DVF may branch out. For instance, take a triangle \tau with three edges \sigma _1, \sigma _2, \sigma _3. We can have a vector \overrightharpoon { \sigma _1 \tau } pointing into the triangle, and \sigma _2, \sigma _3 each having vectors pointing out. Similarly multiple field lines may join when they reach a lower-degree cell. Because of this, we need to take care in the phrasing of admissibility.

Given a discrete vector field, if is admissible if the lengths of the field lines starting from a cell are bounded. In other words, we can assign a natural number to every cell such that the field lines starting from this cell have length bounded by the number. The number can be different for each cell, and can be unbounded overall.

Given a discrete vector field, the discrete version of field lines is defined as a sequence of cells alternating between degree p and (p-1) starting and ending with lower-degree cells, with a few requirements.

ul.li: When the degree increases, the two cells must occur as a vector in the DVF.
When the degree decreases, the degree (p-1) cell must be a (possible non-regular) face of the degree p cell.
Two degree (p-1) cells separated by a degree p cell must not be the same.
